results.title: Field and action potential recordings in heart slices: correlation with established in vitro and in vivo models.
results.text_hl: Here, effects of selected anti@<m>DISEASE_212500</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:212500 @@@-arrhythmics@@@ (@CHEMICAL_Flecainide @CHEMICAL_MESH:D005424 @@@flecainide@@@, @CHEMICAL_Quinidine @CHEMICAL_MESH:D011802 @@@quinidine@@@, @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@, @CHEMICAL_Sotalol @CHEMICAL_MESH:D013015 @@@sotalol@@@, @CHEMICAL_dofetilide @CHEMICAL_MESH:C063533 @@@dofetilide@@@, @CHEMICAL_Nifedipine @CHEMICAL_MESH:D009543 @@@nifedipine@@@, @CHEMICAL_Verapamil @CHEMICAL_MESH:D014700 @@@verapamil@@@) on field/action potentials (FP/AP) of @SPECIES_10141 @@@guinea pig@@@ and @SPECIES_9986 @@@rabbit@@@ ventricular slices are presented and compared with data from established in vitro and in vivo models.

citations.NLM: Himmel HM, Bussek A, Hoffmann M, Beckmann R, Lohmann H, Schmidt M, Wettwer E. Field and action potential recordings in heart slices: correlation with established in vitro and in vivo models. Br J Pharmacol. 2012 May;166(1):276-96. PMID: 22074238
citations.BibTeX: @article{22074238, title={Field and action potential recordings in heart slices: correlation with established in vitro and in vivo models.}, author={Himmel HM and Bussek A and Hoffmann M and Beckmann R and Lohmann H and Schmidt M and Wettwer E}, journal={Br J Pharmacol}, volume={166}, number={1}, pages={276-96}}

results.title: Neurobehavioral contributions to cardiac arrhythmias during aversive pavlovian conditioning in the rabbit receiving digitalis.
results.text_hl: Both parasympathetic and sympathetic involvement were suggested in arrhythmogenesis, since the CS-induced increase in @<m>DISEASE_212500</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:212500 @@@arrhythmic episodes@@@ was blocked by pretreatment with either @CHEMICAL_methylatropine @CHEMICAL_MESH:C006649 @@@atropine methylnitrate@@@ or @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@.

citations.NLM: Markgraf CG, Kapp BS. Neurobehavioral contributions to cardiac arrhythmias during aversive pavlovian conditioning in the rabbit receiving digitalis. J Auton Nerv Syst. 1988 Jun;23(1):35-46. PMID: 3171084
citations.BibTeX: @article{3171084, title={Neurobehavioral contributions to cardiac arrhythmias during aversive pavlovian conditioning in the rabbit receiving digitalis.}, author={Markgraf CG and Kapp BS}, journal={J Auton Nerv Syst}, volume={23}, number={1}, pages={35-46}}

results.title: Transient outward K+ current reduction prolongs action potentials and promotes afterdepolarisations: a dynamic-clamp study in human and rabbit cardiac atrial myocytes.
results.text_hl: ISO+I(TO) decrease-induced @<m>DISEASE_212500</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:212500 @@@CADs@@@ were abolished by @GENE_MS4A1 @GENE_931 @@@beta(1)@@@-antagonism with @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@ at therapeutic concentration (1 mum).

citations.NLM: Workman AJ, Marshall GE, Rankin AC, Smith GL, Dempster J. Transient outward K+ current reduction prolongs action potentials and promotes afterdepolarisations: a dynamic-clamp study in human and rabbit cardiac atrial myocytes. J Physiol. 2012 Sep 1;590(17):4289-305. PMID: 22733660
citations.BibTeX: @article{22733660, title={Transient outward K+ current reduction prolongs action potentials and promotes afterdepolarisations: a dynamic-clamp study in human and rabbit cardiac atrial myocytes.}, author={Workman AJ and Marshall GE and Rankin AC and Smith GL and Dempster J}, journal={J Physiol}, volume={590}, number={17}, pages={4289-305}}

results.title: [Concurrent long QT and Brugada syndrome in a single patient].
results.text_hl: The ECG at this time showed a prolonged QTc of 500 ms in addition to a typical @DISEASE_Brugada_Syndrome @DISEASE_MESH:D053840 @@@Brugada@@@ pattern. @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@Atenolol@@@ was started and after a 36-month follow-up the @SPECIES_9606 @@@patient@@@ has remained asymptomatic without @<m>DISEASE_212500</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:212500 @@@arrhythmic events@@@.

citations.NLM: Martínez Sánchez J, García Alberola A, José Sánchez Muñoz J, Pinar Bermúdez E, A Ruipérez Abizanda J, Valdés Chávarri M. [Concurrent long QT and Brugada syndrome in a single patient]. Rev Esp Cardiol. 2001 May;54(5):645-8. PMID: 11412758
citations.BibTeX: @article{11412758, title={[Concurrent long QT and Brugada syndrome in a single patient].}, author={Martínez Sánchez J and García Alberola A and José Sánchez Muñoz J and Pinar Bermúdez E and A Ruipérez Abizanda J and Valdés Chávarri M}, journal={Rev Esp Cardiol}, volume={54}, number={5}, pages={645-8}}

results.title: Interferences of the autonomic nervous system with drug induced QT prolongation: a point to consider in non-clinical safety studies.
results.text_hl: RESULTS: Two cases of unexpected absence of @DISEASE_Long_QT_Syndrome @DISEASE_MESH:D008133 @@@QT interval prolongation@@@ are reported with @CHEMICAL_Thioridazine @CHEMICAL_MESH:D013881 @@@thioridazine@@@ and @CHEMICAL_Terfenadine @CHEMICAL_MESH:D016593 @@@terfenadine@@@ in conscious @SPECIES_9615 @@@beagle dogs@@@ under conditions of concomitant @DISEASE_Tachycardia @DISEASE_MESH:D013610 @@@tachycardia@@@. The pro-@<m>DISEASE_212500</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:212500 @@@arrhythmic@@@ properties of these two molecules were unmasked by co-treatment with sympatholytic agents, @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@ and @CHEMICAL_Clonidine @CHEMICAL_MESH:D003000 @@@clonidine@@@ respectively suggesting that sympathetic activation and/or parasympathetic withdrawal might impair a drug induced @DISEASE_Long_QT_Syndrome @DISEASE_MESH:D008133 @@@QT prolongation@@@.

citations.NLM: Champeroux P, Ouillé A, Martel E, Fowler JS, Maurin A, Jude S, Lala P, Le Guennec JY, Richard S. Interferences of the autonomic nervous system with drug induced QT prolongation: a point to consider in non-clinical safety studies. J Pharmacol Toxicol Methods. 2010 May-Jun;61(3):251-63. PMID: 20172034
citations.BibTeX: @article{20172034, title={Interferences of the autonomic nervous system with drug induced QT prolongation: a point to consider in non-clinical safety studies.}, author={Champeroux P and Ouillé A and Martel E and Fowler JS and Maurin A and Jude S and Lala P and Le Guennec JY and Richard S}, journal={J Pharmacol Toxicol Methods}, volume={61}, number={3}, pages={251-63}}

results.title: Severe hypoglycemia-induced sudden death is mediated by both cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.
results.text_hl: Adult Sprague-Dawley @SPECIES_10116 @@@rats@@@ were randomized into one of four treatment groups: 1) saline (SAL), 2) anti-@<m>DISEASE_212500</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:212500 @@@arrhythmic@@@ (beta1 blocker @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@), 3) antiseizure (@CHEMICAL_Levetiracetam @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000077287 @@@levetiracetam@@@), and 4) combination antiarrhythmic and antiseizure (beta1 Blocker+@CHEMICAL_Levetiracetam @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000077287 @@@Levetiracetam@@@).

citations.NLM: Reno CM, Skinner A, Bayles J, Chen YS, Daphna-Iken D, Fisher SJ. Severe hypoglycemia-induced sudden death is mediated by both cardiac arrhythmias and seizures. Am J Physiol Endocrinol Metab. 2018 Aug 1;315(2):E240-E249. PMID: 29486140
citations.BibTeX: @article{29486140, title={Severe hypoglycemia-induced sudden death is mediated by both cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.}, author={Reno CM and Skinner A and Bayles J and Chen YS and Daphna-Iken D and Fisher SJ}, journal={Am J Physiol Endocrinol Metab}, volume={315}, number={2}, pages={E240-E249}}
